description: Comprehensive test cases for Radiation Dose Converter calculator

references.ICRP103: ICRP Publication 103 (2007) - The 2007 Recommendations of the ICRP
references.ICRP102: ICRP Publication 102 (2007) - Managing Patient Dose in MDCT
references.AAPM96: AAPM Report No. 96 (2008) - Radiation Dose in CT
references.EC1999: European Commission (1999) - European Guidelines on Quality Criteria for CT

testCases.testName: Absorbed Dose: 1 Gy to all units
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 1 Gy (base unit). Step 2: Convert to mGy = 1 * 1000 = 1000 mGy. Step 3: Convert to cGy = 1 * 100 = 100 cGy. Step 4: Convert to rad = 1 * 100 = 100 rad (since 1 Gy = 100 rad).
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: 1 Gy = 100 rad = 1 J/kg

testCases.testName: Absorbed Dose: 50 mGy to all units (typical CT dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 50 mGy. Step 2: Convert to Gy = 50 * 0.001 = 0.05 Gy. Step 3: From Gy to cGy = 0.05 * 100 = 5 cGy. Step 4: From Gy to rad = 0.05 * 100 = 5 rad.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96: Typical CTDIvol range for body CT

testCases.testName: Absorbed Dose: 200 cGy to all units (radiation therapy dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 200 cGy. Step 2: Convert to Gy = 200 * 0.01 = 2 Gy. Step 3: From Gy to mGy = 2 * 1000 = 2000 mGy. Step 4: cGy equals rad numerically (same conversion factor).
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Radiation therapy typically uses 2 Gy per fraction

testCases.testName: Absorbed Dose: 100 rad to all units (legacy unit conversion)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 100 rad. Step 2: Convert to Gy = 100 * 0.01 = 1 Gy (1 rad = 0.01 Gy). Step 3: From Gy to mGy = 1 * 1000 = 1000 mGy. Step 4: From Gy to cGy = 1 * 100 = 100 cGy.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Legacy unit rad is replaced by Gy in SI (1 Gy = 100 rad)

testCases.testName: Absorbed Dose: Small dose 0.1 mGy
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 0.1 mGy. Step 2: Convert to Gy = 0.1 * 0.001 = 0.0001 Gy. Step 3: From Gy to cGy = 0.0001 * 100 = 0.01 cGy. Step 4: From Gy to rad = 0.0001 * 100 = 0.01 rad.
testCases.medicalReference: Typical dental X-ray absorbed dose range

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose: 1 Sv to all units (photons)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 1 Sv. Step 2: Convert to mSv = 1 * 1000 = 1000 mSv. Step 3: Convert to μSv = 1 * 1,000,000 = 1,000,000 μSv. Step 4: Convert to rem = 1 * 100 = 100 rem. Step 5: Convert to mrem = 1 * 100,000 = 100,000 mrem. Step 6: wR = 1 for photons, so Absorbed Dose = 1 Sv / 1 = 1 Gy.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103 Table A.2: wR = 1 for photons (X-rays, gamma rays)

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose: 10 mSv to all units (typical CT effective dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 10 mSv. Step 2: Convert to Sv = 10 * 0.001 = 0.01 Sv. Step 3: Convert to μSv = 0.01 * 1,000,000 = 10,000 μSv. Step 4: Convert to rem = 0.01 * 100 = 1 rem. Step 5: Convert to mrem = 0.01 * 100,000 = 1000 mrem. Step 6: Background days = 10 / (3/365) = 10 / 0.00822 = 1216.7 days. Step 7: Chest X-rays = 10 / 0.02 = 500.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96: 10 mSv is typical for abdomen/pelvis CT

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose: 100 μSv to all units (chest X-ray range)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 100 μSv. Step 2: Convert to Sv = 100 * 0.000001 = 0.0001 Sv. Step 3: Convert to mSv = 0.0001 * 1000 = 0.1 mSv. Step 4: Convert to rem = 0.0001 * 100 = 0.01 rem. Step 5: Convert to mrem = 0.0001 * 100,000 = 10 mrem.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: PA+Lat chest X-ray approximately 0.1 mSv

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose: 5 rem to all units (legacy occupational dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 5 rem. Step 2: Convert to Sv = 5 * 0.01 = 0.05 Sv. Step 3: Convert to mSv = 0.05 * 1000 = 50 mSv. Step 4: Convert to μSv = 0.05 * 1,000,000 = 50,000 μSv. Step 5: Convert to mrem = 5 * 1000 = 5000 mrem.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Annual occupational limit is 50 mSv (5 rem)

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose: 500 mrem to all units
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 500 mrem. Step 2: Convert to Sv = 500 * 0.00001 = 0.005 Sv. Step 3: Convert to mSv = 0.005 * 1000 = 5 mSv. Step 4: Convert to μSv = 0.005 * 1,000,000 = 5,000 μSv. Step 5: Convert to rem = 0.005 * 100 = 0.5 rem.
testCases.medicalReference: NCRP Report 160: 500 mrem approximates 2 months of US average background

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose with Alpha Particles (wR=20): 1 mSv
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 1 mSv = 0.001 Sv. Step 2: wR for alpha = 20. Step 3: Absorbed Dose = Equivalent Dose / wR = 0.001 Sv / 20 = 0.00005 Gy = 0.05 mGy. Step 4: This means 0.05 mGy of alpha radiation produces 1 mSv equivalent dose.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103 Table A.2: wR = 20 for alpha particles and heavy nuclei

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose with Protons (wR=2): 5 mSv
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 5 mSv = 0.005 Sv. Step 2: wR for protons = 2 (ICRP 103 reduced from 5 in ICRP 60). Step 3: Absorbed Dose = 0.005 Sv / 2 = 0.0025 Gy = 2.5 mGy. Step 4: 2.5 mGy of proton radiation produces 5 mSv equivalent dose.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103 Table A.2: wR = 2 for protons (reduced from wR = 5 in ICRP 60)

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose with Beta/Electrons (wR=1): 2 mSv
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 2 mSv = 0.002 Sv. Step 2: wR for beta/electrons = 1. Step 3: Absorbed Dose = 0.002 Sv / 1 = 0.002 Gy = 2 mGy. Step 4: For wR = 1, absorbed dose equals equivalent dose numerically.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103 Table A.2: wR = 1 for electrons and muons

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose with Low-Energy Neutrons (wR=5): 10 mSv
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 10 mSv = 0.01 Sv. Step 2: wR for neutrons < 10 keV = 5. Step 3: Absorbed Dose = 0.01 Sv / 5 = 0.002 Gy = 2 mGy. Step 4: Low-energy neutrons have wR = 5 per ICRP 103.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Neutron wR is energy-dependent, ranging from 2.5 to 20.7

testCases.testName: Equivalent Dose with Medium-Energy Neutrons (wR=20): 20 mSv
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 20 mSv = 0.02 Sv. Step 2: wR for neutrons 100 keV - 2 MeV = 20 (maximum). Step 3: Absorbed Dose = 0.02 Sv / 20 = 0.001 Gy = 1 mGy. Step 4: Medium-energy neutrons have highest wR.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Maximum neutron wR ~20 at approximately 1 MeV

testCases.testName: Activity: 1 Ci to all units
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 1 Ci. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 1 * 3.7e10 = 3.7e10 Bq (definition: 1 Ci = 3.7e10 disintegrations/second). Step 3: To kBq = 3.7e10 / 1e3 = 3.7e7 kBq. Step 4: To MBq = 3.7e10 / 1e6 = 37,000 MBq. Step 5: To GBq = 3.7e10 / 1e9 = 37 GBq. Step 6: To mCi = 1 * 1000 = 1000 mCi. Step 7: To μCi = 1 * 1e6 = 1e6 μCi.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: 1 Ci = 3.7 x 10^10 Bq (based on activity of 1 gram of Ra-226)

testCases.testName: Activity: 370 MBq to all units (typical FDG PET dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 370 MBq. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 370 * 1e6 = 3.7e8 Bq. Step 3: To kBq = 3.7e8 / 1e3 = 3.7e5 kBq. Step 4: To GBq = 3.7e8 / 1e9 = 0.37 GBq. Step 5: To Ci = 3.7e8 / 3.7e10 = 0.01 Ci. Step 6: To mCi = 0.01 * 1000 = 10 mCi.
testCases.medicalReference: EANM Guidelines: 370 MBq (10 mCi) is lower end of typical F-18 FDG PET dose

testCases.testName: Activity: 740 MBq to all units (typical bone scan dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 740 MBq. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 740 * 1e6 = 7.4e8 Bq. Step 3: To GBq = 7.4e8 / 1e9 = 0.74 GBq. Step 4: To Ci = 7.4e8 / 3.7e10 = 0.02 Ci. Step 5: To mCi = 0.02 * 1000 = 20 mCi.
testCases.medicalReference: SNM Guidelines: 740 MBq (20 mCi) is typical Tc-99m MDP bone scan dose

testCases.testName: Activity: 25 mCi to all units (nuclear medicine dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 25 mCi. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 25 * 3.7e7 = 9.25e8 Bq. Step 3: To MBq = 9.25e8 / 1e6 = 925 MBq. Step 4: To GBq = 9.25e8 / 1e9 = 0.925 GBq. Step 5: To Ci = 25 / 1000 = 0.025 Ci. Step 6: To μCi = 25 * 1000 = 25,000 μCi.
testCases.medicalReference: SNM Guidelines: 25 mCi upper range for Tc-99m bone scans

testCases.testName: Activity: 100 μCi to all units (tracer dose)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 100 μCi. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 100 * 3.7e4 = 3.7e6 Bq. Step 3: To kBq = 3.7e6 / 1e3 = 3,700 kBq. Step 4: To MBq = 3.7e6 / 1e6 = 3.7 MBq. Step 5: To mCi = 100 / 1000 = 0.1 mCi.
testCases.medicalReference: Typical low-activity tracer or research dose range

testCases.testName: Activity: 3.7 GBq to all units (I-131 therapy low)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 3.7 GBq. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 3.7 * 1e9 = 3.7e9 Bq. Step 3: To MBq = 3.7e9 / 1e6 = 3,700 MBq. Step 4: To Ci = 3.7e9 / 3.7e10 = 0.1 Ci. Step 5: To mCi = 0.1 * 1000 = 100 mCi.
testCases.medicalReference: ATA Guidelines: 3.7 GBq (100 mCi) typical for thyroid cancer I-131 ablation

testCases.testName: CT Head Dose: Adult, CTDIvol 60 mGy, 20 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 60 * 20 = 1200 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for head = 0.0021 mSv/(mGy·cm) from ICRP 102. Step 3: Effective Dose = DLP * k = 1200 * 0.0021 = 2.52 mSv. Step 4: Age multiplier for adult = 1.0. Step 5: Final dose = 2.52 * 1.0 = 2.52 mSv. Step 6: Chest X-ray equiv = 2.52 / 0.02 = 126.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96 Table 1: k = 0.0021 for head (16 cm phantom)

testCases.testName: CT Chest Dose: Adult, CTDIvol 10 mGy, 35 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 10 * 35 = 350 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for chest = 0.014 mSv/(mGy·cm) from ICRP 102. Step 3: Effective Dose = DLP * k = 350 * 0.014 = 4.90 mSv. Step 4: Age multiplier for adult = 1.0. Step 5: Final dose = 4.90 * 1.0 = 4.90 mSv. Step 6: Chest X-ray equiv = 4.90 / 0.02 = 245.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96 Table 1: k = 0.014 for chest (32 cm phantom)

testCases.testName: CT Abdomen/Pelvis Dose: Adult, CTDIvol 15 mGy, 50 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 15 * 50 = 750 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for abdomen = 0.015 mSv/(mGy·cm) from ICRP 102. Step 3: Effective Dose = DLP * k = 750 * 0.015 = 11.25 mSv. Step 4: Age multiplier for adult = 1.0. Step 5: Final dose = 11.25 * 1.0 = 11.25 mSv. Step 6: Chest X-ray equiv = 11.25 / 0.02 = 562.5 ≈ 563.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96 Table 1: k = 0.015 for abdomen (32 cm phantom)

testCases.testName: CT Neck Dose: Adult, CTDIvol 25 mGy, 15 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 25 * 15 = 375 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for neck = 0.0059 mSv/(mGy·cm) from ICRP 102. Step 3: Effective Dose = DLP * k = 375 * 0.0059 = 2.2125 mSv. Step 4: Age multiplier for adult = 1.0. Step 5: Final dose = 2.21 mSv (rounded). Step 6: Chest X-ray equiv = 2.21 / 0.02 = 110.6 ≈ 111.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96 Table 1: k = 0.0059 for neck (16 cm phantom)

testCases.testName: CT Trunk/CAP Dose: Adult, CTDIvol 12 mGy, 70 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 12 * 70 = 840 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for trunk/CAP = 0.015 mSv/(mGy·cm). Step 3: Effective Dose = DLP * k = 840 * 0.015 = 12.60 mSv. Step 4: Age multiplier for adult = 1.0. Step 5: Final dose = 12.60 mSv.
testCases.medicalReference: AAPM Report 96: CAP (chest-abdomen-pelvis) uses k = 0.015

testCases.testName: Pediatric CT Head: 5-year-old, CTDIvol 40 mGy, 18 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 40 * 18 = 720 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for head = 0.0021 mSv/(mGy·cm). Step 3: Adult Effective Dose = DLP * k = 720 * 0.0021 = 1.512 mSv. Step 4: Pediatric age multiplier for 5-year-old = 1.5. Step 5: Pediatric Effective Dose = 1.512 * 1.5 = 2.268 mSv ≈ 2.27 mSv.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 102 / EC Guidelines: Pediatric patients have higher tissue radiosensitivity

testCases.testName: Pediatric CT Chest: 1-year-old, CTDIvol 5 mGy, 20 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 5 * 20 = 100 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for chest = 0.014 mSv/(mGy·cm). Step 3: Adult Effective Dose = DLP * k = 100 * 0.014 = 1.40 mSv. Step 4: Pediatric age multiplier for 1-year-old = 1.9. Step 5: Pediatric Effective Dose = 1.40 * 1.9 = 2.66 mSv.
testCases.medicalReference: Image Gently Campaign: Pediatric CT requires significantly reduced protocols

testCases.testName: Pediatric CT Abdomen: Newborn, CTDIvol 3 mGy, 15 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 3 * 15 = 45 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for abdomen = 0.015 mSv/(mGy·cm). Step 3: Adult Effective Dose = DLP * k = 45 * 0.015 = 0.675 mSv. Step 4: Pediatric age multiplier for newborn = 2.25 (highest). Step 5: Pediatric Effective Dose = 0.675 * 2.25 = 1.519 mSv ≈ 1.52 mSv.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 102: Newborn multiplier 2.25× reflects increased radiosensitivity

testCases.testName: Pediatric CT: 10-year-old chest, CTDIvol 8 mGy, 30 cm scan
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: DLP = CTDIvol * scan_length = 8 * 30 = 240 mGy·cm. Step 2: k-factor for chest = 0.014 mSv/(mGy·cm). Step 3: Adult Effective Dose = DLP * k = 240 * 0.014 = 3.36 mSv. Step 4: Pediatric age multiplier for 10-year-old = 1.2. Step 5: Pediatric Effective Dose = 3.36 * 1.2 = 4.032 mSv ≈ 4.03 mSv.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 102: 10-year-old multiplier 1.2× approaching adult values

testCases.testName: Dose Context: Less than chest X-ray (0.01 mSv)

expectedOutputs.Context: Less than a chest X-ray (0.02 mSv)

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 0.01 mSv. Step 2: Background days = 0.01 / (3/365) = 0.01 / 0.00822 = 1.22 days. Step 3: Chest X-rays = 0.01 / 0.02 = 0.5 ≈ 1. Step 4: Context: 0.01 < 0.02, so 'Less than a chest X-ray'.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: PA chest X-ray typically 0.02 mSv

testCases.testName: Dose Context: Similar to 1 year background (3 mSv)

expectedOutputs.Context: Similar to CT chest range (4-8 mSv)

testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 3 mSv. Step 2: Background days = 3 / (3/365) = 3 / 0.00822 = 365 days. Step 3: Chest X-rays = 3 / 0.02 = 150. Step 4: Context: 3 mSv is in range 3-8, so 'Similar to CT chest range'.
testCases.medicalReference: NCRP Report 160: US average background ~3 mSv/year

testCases.testName: Dose Context: Approaching occupational limit (45 mSv)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 45 mSv. Step 2: Background days = 45 / 0.00822 = 5474.5 ≈ 5475 days (~15 years). Step 3: Chest X-rays = 45 / 0.02 = 2250. Step 4: Context: 15 < 45 < 50, so 'Approaching annual occupational limit'.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Annual occupational limit 50 mSv, 5-year average 20 mSv

testCases.testName: Dose Context: Exceeds occupational limit (75 mSv)
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 75 mSv. Step 2: Chest X-rays = 75 / 0.02 = 3750. Step 3: Context: 75 > 50, so 'Exceeds annual occupational limit'.
testCases.medicalReference: ICRP 103: Exceeding 50 mSv annual limit requires dose reduction measures

testCases.testName: Edge Case: Zero input value
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 0 Gy. Step 2: All conversions = 0 (multiplication by 0). Step 3: Display '0 [unit]' format.
testCases.medicalReference: N/A - boundary condition test

testCases.testName: Edge Case: Very large activity value
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 1000 Ci. Step 2: Convert to Bq = 1000 * 3.7e10 = 3.7e13 Bq. Step 3: Large values use exponential notation. Step 4: To GBq = 3.7e13 / 1e9 = 37,000 GBq.
testCases.medicalReference: Industrial/reactor source level activity

testCases.testName: Edge Case: Very small dose value
testCases.calculationSteps: Step 1: Input = 0.001 μSv = 1e-9 Sv. Step 2: Very small values display with appropriate precision. Step 3: To mSv = 1e-9 * 1000 = 1e-6 mSv.
testCases.medicalReference: Negligible dose level, below measurement threshold

validationNotes.conversionAccuracy: All conversion factors verified against ICRP 103 (2007) and AAPM Report 96 (2008)
validationNotes.kFactorSource: k-factors from ICRP Publication 102 and European Commission EUR 16262
validationNotes.pediatricMultipliers: Age-specific multipliers based on EC Guidelines and ICRP 102
validationNotes.roundingBehavior: Results use toFixed(4) for values >= 1, toFixed(6) for values 0.0001-1, exponential for very small/large
